title: keen 1 pc sounds?
content: I wanted to play keen 1 but it is pc sounds. can i turn this off or is there a mod to turn it off?[img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-deadkeenvort.gif[/img]

title: Re: keen 1 pc sounds?
content: You could play it in [url=http://dosbox.sourceforge.net]DOSBox[/url], which puts the PC sounds through your normal speakers - then you could just turn off your speakers.

title: Re: keen 1 pc sounds?
content: i already play it on DOSbox, but still it use the pc sounds[img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-sad.gif[/img]

title: Re: keen 1 pc sounds?
content:
Press F2, if I remember correct, and you can toggle the sound off. If it wasn't F2 try other F-keys.3D Realms: "Do you think there'll ever be a sequel to your game(s)?"
Tom Hall: "If I owned Keen, there sure would be. I don't consider that GBA game canon by any means."

title: Re: keen 1 pc sounds?
content: ok i'm gotta check it out[img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]  thanks.

title: Beepity
content: But why would you want to turn it off? Those sounds are one of the most beautiful things this world has to offer.

title: beautiful?
content: what? beautiful? it sounds like bleep blap blup!

title: Re: beautiful?
content:
Agree with Spleen -- on some level -- I wouldn't turn them off, they're pretty good.3D Realms: "Do you think there'll ever be a sequel to your game(s)?"
Tom Hall: "If I owned Keen, there sure would be. I don't consider that GBA game canon by any means."

title: Re: beautiful?
content:
I never turn them off, because of their Keenish feeling or something. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img] But they go through my actual speakers anyway, even in DOS, because I have a laptop.

How come people here didn't know of F2? It's been there all the time...____________
Don't think of me as an ordinary man.

Even though I am an ordinary man.

title: Re: *nostalgifies*
content:
(kind of on the topic idea,) personally, I don't really like how DosBox emulates the PC speaker. It's quite rudimentary (the complex sounds in Keen 1-3 don't are horribly simplified, at least on my computer), and it doesn't really sound like any PC speaker that I've ever owned.--------------------

title: Re: *nostalgifies*
content: Any particular sounds you've noticed this on?  Yet again I've never noticed a difference between DOSBox and the real thing (other than the DOSBox emulated PC speaker being much sharper and higher clarity), but I do have a DOS PC handy I could go listen to.

title: Re: *nostalgifies*
content:
Although I do understand the want to turn off the PC speaker. On my other, stable computer the PC speaker is INCREDIBLY LOUD. Just the single beep for the bootup could be heard all over the house. When I tried playing Keen1 a few years back my sister got mad and told me to turn it off.

I simply unpluged the PC speaker. I no longer hear the obnoxious beep on boot. Since then I did that to ALL my computers.

I love a quiet system.[img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-love.gif[/img] -----------------------
The end of this post. You may stop reading now.

title: Re: *nostalgifies*
content:
You can unplug a PC speaker?

[img]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v499/Nevad/menbun.gif[/img]

Awww! Feel the love!

title: Re: *nostalgifies*
content:
You can unplug some of them, but many are built into the motherboard.

As for whether DOSbox sounds authentic, I don't think it's really possible to even answer that. Computers all have their own "voice", since some have little tiny piezo speakers, others have larger ones, and yet more have dynamic speakers. And others get output jacks wired in so you can run them to the sound system .[img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-grin.gif[/img] DOSbox sounds about normal to me.________________
[img]http://img80.imageshack.us/img80/8498/missouriansf9.png[/img]

title: Re: *nostalgifies*
content:
You can stick a blob of blu-tac onto most onboard PC speakers to reduce them to a nice quiet volume. Of course many mobos like this have a connector for an external speaker, which has a jumper across it to enable the onboard speaker - if you unplug the jumper but don't plug in an external speaker, the onboard one gets switched off.

And others get output jacks wired in so you can run them to the sound system

Heh, well my PC speaker is plugged into my Audigy which is in turn connected to my hi-fi, so yeah, I guess you could say I have 100 watt 7.1 channel PC speaker sound...

title: Re: *nostalgifies*

In my experience it also depends on what kind of computer you have. I have had some computers where the PC speaker was so harsh and LOUD I disconnected it. Then had some computers where the PC speaker was synthesized through the sound card. (And sounded pretty good too.)-----------------------
